Colston's statue is problematic because he profited from slavery, but it is also problematic because the statue itself was deliberately designed to use the symbolic power of philanthropy to promote other values and ideas we should be uncomfortable about. 22/

This excellent article highlights how Colston was chosen because he exemplified a notion of the benificient merchant venturer that the men who led the campaign for his statue were keen to promote: 12/

The Colston statue was erected in 1895, long after slavery was abolished. The question then is, why Colston and not some other Bristol philanthropist? (Of whom there are many who gave more than Colston and don't have such links). 11/

Firstly, the statue def doesn't teach us anything about slavery (despite claims of some trying to justify it). BUT neither does it tell us much about philanthropy in Colston's time . What it teaches us about is philanthropy in the Victorian era- when the statue was erected. 9/

But. The thing we need to realise is that trying to use philanthropy to preclude/excuse how wealth was generated isn't incidental to a statue like Colston's, or something thought up after the fact. It was arguably the whole point of the statue in the first place. 7/

We can see that Colston's philanthropy is still a central part of the defence for those who have resisted the statue's amendment or removal. This "whataboutism"- trying to counterbalance the ill of slavery with the purported good of philanthropy- is hugely problematic IMHO. 5/

It's possible to have statutes that commemorate without celebrating, but suggestion that this applies to Colston is disingenuous. There is no mention of slavery on the statue (despite repeated campaigning efforts)- which is important in understanding how philanthropy fits in. 4/
